facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1961 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 22, 1961,

facts.text: Punjab High Court judgment and order dated May 22, 1961 in Criminal Revision No. 1448 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated May 22, 1961, of the Punjab High Court, Chandigarh in Criminal Revision No. 1448 of 1960. K. Kapur, for the appellants.

facts.text: Jagir Kaur, first wife of Jaswant Singh, married in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Jagir Kaur, the first wife of jaswant Singh, was married to him in 1.930. Tile said jaswant Singh was employed in the police force in Africa.

facts.text: Jaswant Singh employed in police force in Africa.

anchor.surface_text: Tile said jaswant Singh was employed in the police force in Africa. The Maklawa ceremony took place about 7 years after the marriage,

facts.text: Maklawa ceremony took place about 7 years after the marriage when respondent was in Africa.

anchor.surface_text: The Maklawa ceremony took place about 7 years after the marriage, when the respondent was away In Africa. Thereafter, the first appellant was taken to her mother-in-laws house,

facts.text: First appellant lived in mother-in-law's house for a few years then returned to parental house.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the first appellant was taken to her mother-in-laws house, and after living there for a few years she returned to her parental house.

facts.text: 5 or 6 years later, Jaswant Singh came to India on 5 months leave and lived with first appellant in Hans Kalan for 5 months.

anchor.surface_text: 5 or 6 years thereafter, jaswant Singh came to India on 5 months leave and the companyple lived in jaswant Singhs or his mothers house at Hans Kalan it is number clear to whom the house belongs-for a period of 5 months

facts.text: Jaswant Singh then left for Africa and married another wife whom he took to Africa.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter jaswant Singh left for Africa. Before going to Africa, jaswant Singh married another wife and took her with him to Africa.

facts.text: After 5 or 6 years, Jaswant Singh came back to India on leave and took first appellant to Africa.

anchor.surface_text: After 5 or 6 years, he came back to India on leave and took the first appellant also to Africa.

facts.text: First appellant gave birth to second appellant (daughter) in Africa.

anchor.surface_text: There she gave birth to a daughter the second appellant. As disputes arose between them, he sent her back to India,

facts.text: Jaswant Singh sent first appellant back to India promising maintenance but did not send money.

anchor.surface_text: As disputes arose between them, he sent her back to India, promising to send her money for her maintenance but did number  lo so.

facts.text: In 1960, Jaswant Singh came back to India and purchased property in Ludhiana District for Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1960, he came back to India. It is also in evidence that he had purchased property in Ludhiana District for Rs. 25,000/-

facts.text: First appellant filed petition under s.488 CrPC in First Class Magistrate Ludhiana while respondent was staying there.

anchor.surface_text: When he was admittedly in India, the first appellant filed a petition under s. 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the Court of the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana, within whose jurisdiction the respondent was staying at that time.

facts.text: Petition claimed Rs.200 per month maintenance for wife and minor daughter on ground of desertion and non-maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was filed by the first appellant on behalf of herself and also as lawful guardian of the second appellant, who was a minor, claiming maintenance at Rs. 200/- per month for both of them on the ground that the respondent deserted them and did number maintain them.

facts.text: Respondent filed counter-affidavit denying allegations and claiming no jurisdiction as never resided or last resided with wife in Ludhiana district.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a companynter-affidavit denying the allegations and pleading that the said companyrt had numberon the ground that he never resided within its district number did he last reside with the first appellant in any place within its.jurisdiction.

facts.text: Magistrate held petitioner is wife, court had jurisdiction as last resided together in Ludhiana, awarded Rs.100 to wife and Rs.50 to daughter per month.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate held that the petitioner-appellant was the wife of the respondent and that the Court had jurisdiction to entertain the petition as the husband and wife last resided together in the District of Ludhiana. On the merits, he held that the first wife and her daughter were entitled to maintenance and awarded for the wife maintenance at the rate of Rs. 100/- per month and for the daughter at the rate of Rs. 50/- per month.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge Ludhiana upheld Magistrate on jurisdiction and maintenance, dismissed revision.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred a revision against that order to the Additional Sessions judge, Ludhiana, and the learned Addi- tional Sessions judge, agreed with the learned Magistrate both on the question of jurisdiction and also on the right to maintenance and dismissed the revision.

facts.text: Punjab High Court held no jurisdiction as permanent home in Africa, visits temporary, set aside order and dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The husband preferred a revision to the High Court of Punjab against that order. The High Court disagreed with both the lower Courts on the question of jurisdiction. It held that the husbands permanent home was Africa and his two visits to Ludhiana for temporary periods did number make him one who resided in that district or who last resided with his wife therein. On that view, it set aside the order of the learned Additional Sessions judge and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Magistrate Ludhiana had jurisdiction as respondent last resided with wife in Ludhiana and was present when petition filed.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that he last resided with her in a place within the jurisdiction of the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana. That apart, it is admitted that he was in a place within the jurisdiction of the said Magistrate on the date when the appellant filed her application for maintenance against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court restored Magistrate's order on maintenance quantum.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the view accepted by the High Court was wrong, we set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana.

facts.text: Respondent born in Ludhiana District, India.

anchor.surface_text: To recapitulate the relevant facts the respondent was born in India in Ludhiana District he was married to the first appellant in the year 1930

facts.text: Respondent's mother staying in Hans Kalan village, Ludhiana District.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents mother is staying in the aforesaid village in the same district and it is also number disputed that the respondent has purchased property worth Rs. 25,000/-

facts.text: Respondent purchased property Rs.25,000 in Ludhiana in name of minor children by second wife.

anchor.surface_text: and it is also number disputed that the respondent has purchased property worth Rs. 25,000/- in Ludhiana District in the name of his minor children by his second wife

facts.text: Notice served on respondent in Ludhiana district, filed counter-affidavit, obtained exemption from appearance then left for Africa.

anchor.surface_text: when the petition was filed he was admittedly in the district of Ludhiana---indeed, numberice was served on him in that district, he filed a companynter affidavit, obtained exemption from personal appearance at the time of hearing and thereafter left for Africa.

holdings.text: We cannot therefore, permit the first appellant to raise this belated plea.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot therefore, permit the first appellant to raise this belated plea. The only question in the appeal is whether the Magistrate of Ludhiana had jurisdiction to entertain the petition filed under s. 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised in pleadings or lower courts; mixed question of fact and law not allowed first time in Supreme Court without exceptional circumstances.

holdings.text: a person resides in a place if he through choice makes it his abode permanently or even temporarily whether a person has chosen to make a particular place his abode depends upon the facts of each case.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the object sought to be achieved, the meaning implicit in the words used, and the construction placed by decided cases thereon, we would define the word resides thus a person resides in a place if he through choice makes it his abode permanently or even temporarily

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual meaning, purposive interpretation for summary relief to helpless wife/child, supported by precedents requiring animus manendi beyond flying visit.

holdings.text: s. 488(8) of the Code, when it speaks of a district where a person last resided with his wife, can only mean where he last resided with his wife in any district in India other than Jammu Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that s. 488 8  of the Code, when it speaks of a district where a person last resided with his wife, can only mean where he last resided with his wife in any district in India other than Jammu Kashmir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption against extra-territoriality; s.2 CrPC limits Code to India; cannot confer jurisdiction based on foreign residence.

holdings.text: The verb is connotes in the context the presence or the existence of the person in the district when the proceedings are taken. It is much wider than the word resides...

anchor.surface_text: The third expression is the word is. It is inserted between the words resides and last resided. The word, therefore, cannot be given the same meaning as the word resides or the expression last resided bears. The meaning of the word is apparent if the relevant part of the subsection is read.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction distinguishes from 'resides'; mere physical presence suffices for jurisdiction to provide urgent relief.

holdings.text: In the circumstances we must hold that he last resided with her in a place within the jurisdiction of the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that he last resided with her in a place within the jurisdiction of the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana. That apart, it is admitted that he was in a place within the jurisdiction of the said Magistrate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show 5-month stay in Hans Kalan with animus manendi qualifies as temporary residence under s.488(8).

holdings.text: That apart, it is admitted that he was in a place within the jurisdiction of the said Magistrate on the date when the appellant filed her application for maintenance against him. The said Magistrate had jurisdiction to entertain the petition, as the said proceedings can be taken against any person in any district where he is.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, it is admitted that he was in a place within the jurisdiction of the said Magistrate on the date when the appellant filed her application for maintenance against him. Thee said Magistrate had jurisdiction to entertain the petition, as the said proceedings can be taken against any person in any district where he is.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted presence in district when petition filed satisfies 'is' under s.488(8).

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana, had jurisdiction to entertain the petition under s. 488 8  of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore-, hold that the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana, had jurisdiction to entertain the petition under s. 488  8  of the Code. The next question relates to the quantum of maintenance to be awarded to the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying construction of s.488(8) to facts of last residence and presence.

holdings.text: The finding is a concurrent finding of fact the correctness whereof cannot ordinarily be questioned in a revision petition in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The finding is a concurrent finding of fact the correctness whereof cannot ordinarily be questioned in a revision petition in the High Court. that is why the only question argued before the High Court was that of jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings by Magistrate and Sessions Judge on quantum based on evidence of salary and property; not disturbed in revision.

holdings.text: As we have held that the view accepted by the High Court was wrong, we set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the view accepted by the High Court was wrong, we set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on jurisdiction; lower courts correct on jurisdiction and maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: In Santpoornam v. N. Sundaregan 1 , it was held that the word resides implied something more than 1 1952 2 M.L.J 573, a brief visit. but number such companytinuity as to amount to a domicile.

precedents.cited_proposition: the word resides implied something more than a brief visit but not such continuity as to amount to a domicile

precedents.citation: Khairunissa v. Bashir Ahmed 1 1929 I.L.R. 53 Bom. 781

anchor.surface_text: In Khairunissa v. Bashir Ahmed 1 , on a companysideration of the relevant authorities it wits pointed out that a casual or a flying visit to a place was excluded from the scope of the word resides.

precedents.cited_proposition: a casual or a flying visit to a place was excluded from the scope of the word resides

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of the Allahabad High Court, in Flowers v. Flowers 2 , expressed the view that a mere casual residence in a place for a temporary purpose with numberintention of remaining was number. companyered by the word resides.

precedents.cited_proposition: a mere casual residence in a place for a temporary purpose with no intention of remaining was not covered by the word resides

precedents.citation: Balakrishna v. Sakuntala Bai 3 A.I.R. 1942 Mad. 666

anchor.surface_text: In Balakrishna v. Sakuntala Bai 3  it was held that the expression reside implied something more than stay and implied some intention to remain at a place and number merely to pay it a casual visit.

precedents.cited_proposition: the expression reside implied something more than stay and implied some intention to remain at a place and not merely to pay it a casual visit

precedents.citation: Charan Das v. Surasti Bai 2 A.I.R. 1940 Lah. 449

anchor.surface_text: In Charan Das v. Surasti Bai 2 , it was held that the sole test on the question of residence was whether a party had animus manendi, or an intention to stay for an indefinite period, at one place and if he had such an intention, then alone companyld he be said to reside there.

precedents.cited_proposition: the sole test on the question of residence was whether a party had animus manendi, or an intention to stay for an indefinite period, at one place and if he had such an intention, then alone could he be said to reside there

precedents.citation: In re Drucker No. 2 Basden, Ex Parte 1 1902 2 K.B. 210

anchor.surface_text: In In re Drucker No. 2 Basden, Ex Parte the words or in any other place out of England, in sub-s. 6 of s. 27 of the Bankruptcy Act, 1883, fell to be companystrued. The words were wide enough to enable a Court in England to order that any person who, if in England, would be liable to be brought before it under the section, shall be examined in any place out of England, including a place number within the jurisdiction of the British Crown. The Court held that the words must be read with some limitation and the jurisdiction companyferred by that section does number extend to places abroad which are number within the jurisdiction of the British Crown.

precedents.case_name: In re Drucker No. 2 Basden, Ex Parte
precedents.cited_proposition: the words must be read with some limitation and the jurisdiction conferred by that section does not extend to places abroad which are not within the jurisdiction of the British Crown
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to me that that restriction in prima facie necessary. It is impossible to suppose that the Legislature intended to empower the Court to order the examination of persons in foreign countries for instance, in France or Germany.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the view accepted by the High Court was wrong, we set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order set aside; Magistrate's order awarding Rs. 100/- per month to wife and Rs. 50/- per month to daughter restored
directions: set aside the order of the High Court
restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana

anchor.surface_text: We cannot therefore, permit the first appellant to raise this belated plea. The only question in the appeal is whether the Magistrate of Ludhiana had jurisdiction to entertain the petition filed under s. 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that s. 488 8  of the Code, when it speaks of a district where a person last resided with his wife, can only mean where he last resided with his wife in any district in India other than Jammu Kashmir.
As we have held that the view accepted by the High Court was wrong, we set aside the order of the High Court and restore that of the Magistrate First Class, Ludhiana.
